G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28, a custody or parenting order may be modified if there has been a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child and if such modification is necessary in the child’s best interests.

G.L. c. 209, \u00a7 37.proposition: The Plaintiff, Jessica Turner, residing in Berkshire County, Massachusetts, respectfully brings this Complaint pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209, § 37, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, seeking modification of an existing custody order entered by this Court on May 15, 2018.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: To further support this Petition, Plaintiff invokes the Court’s equitable authority under G.L. c. 215, § 6 allowing modification of judgments concerning custody when equitable circumstances require.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31.proposition: Plaintiff respectfully submits that continuing the current 50/50 custody schedule poses safety and emotional concerns for the minor child and now conflicts with her best interests as defined by G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 31, both parents share equally in parental rights and responsibilities, but the court must consider the capacity of each parent to provide the child’s needs and welfare.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: The law is well established that the best interests of the child standard governs all custody determinations.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the governing standard in custody cases, describing the ‘best interests of the child’ as the longstanding and controlling principle for custody determinations in Massachusetts. The court traces the history of the best-interests standard, reaffirms that it “always” remains the paramount concern in custody matters, and applies that standard in deciding the case, thereby supporting the proposition that custody determinations are governed by the best interests of the child standard.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.proposition: The law is well established that the best interests of the child standard governs all custody determinations.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly applies the best interests of the child concept (including via citation to prior cases and the statute), but the provided excerpt does not contain a clear, general statement that *all* custody determinations are governed by that standard. The focus here is on requiring explicit findings regarding domestic violence within the already-accepted best-interests framework, not on articulating or reaffirming a broad, general rule about all custody determinations. Thus it is consistent with, but not strong authority for, the sweeping proposition as stated.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.relevant_excerpt: "To the same effect, see the definition of ‘[s]hared physical custody,’ G. L. c. 208, § 31 (1994 ed.): ‘In determining whether temporary shared legal custody would not be in the best interest of the child, the court shall consider ... whether any member of the family has been the perpetrator of domestic violence.’"

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (20.proposition: Substantial changes in a parent’s health or ability to provide safe care constitute grounds for modification.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (20.support_reasoning: The case concerns the standard for permitting removal of children from the Commonwealth where parents share joint legal and physical custody. It analyzes what constitutes “cause shown” under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and applies a best-interests-of-the-child test in the relocation context. It does not address modification of custody based on substantial changes in a parent’s health or ability to provide safe care, nor does it establish that such health or safety changes constitute grounds for modification.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (20.relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]….’ … [T]he court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests… taking into account all relevant factors including the effects of the relocation on the child.’”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Substantial changes in a parent’s health or ability to provide safe care constitute grounds for modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses when a custody order may be modified, but it does not involve or analyze any change in a parent’s health or ability to provide safe care. Instead, it holds that relocation alone, and a temporary court-imposed custody change, are not material and substantial changes justifying modification. The court explicitly finds both parents have safe and secure homes and does not ground modification on any health or safety deterioration, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’ Tolos v. Tolos, 11 Mass. App. Ct. 708, 710-711 (1981) (citation omitted).”}

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Courts have repeatedly held that when changed circumstances render an existing schedule impracticable or detrimental, modification may be warranted.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The case concerns initial custody and removal of children to another country, not modification of an existing parenting or visitation schedule based on changed circumstances. The court articulates standards for determining the children’s best interests and the custodial parent’s ‘real advantage’ in relocating, but it does not discuss or decide when an already-entered schedule becomes impracticable or detrimental such that modification is warranted. Therefore it does not support the proposition about modification for changed circumstances.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619, 625 (2.proposition: Courts have repeatedly held that when changed circumstances render an existing schedule impracticable or detrimental, modification may be warranted.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619, 625 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with modification of a custody arrangement only in the narrow sense of requiring that any future change in custody occur via a complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28, rather than by motion. It does not discuss the substantive standard for when modification is warranted, such as when changed circumstances make an existing schedule impracticable or detrimental. Thus, it does not provide authority for the cited general proposition about modification based on changed circumstances.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619, 625 (2.relevant_excerpt: A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 227 (19.proposition: Cases interpreting this standard emphasize safety and stability.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 227 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion applies the G.L. c. 210, § 3 best-interests standard and expressly highlights the importance of stability and a predictable environment, particularly for a young child with special needs. The court repeatedly frames the analysis in terms of the child’s need for a stable, structured, and consistent home and weighs competing adoption plans by reference to long-term developmental support and stable caregiving. This treatment shows that cases interpreting the best-interests standard emphasize safety- and stability-related considerations.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 227 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Hugo is a child with special needs… He has behavioral and emotional difficulties, displaying a low tolerance for frustration and difficulty with transitions. The judge found that Hugo needs a ‘consistent and predictable’ environment… Stability in the life of a child, especially one as young as Hugo, is important, as the judge himself recognized. Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 617 (1986). Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Cases interpreting this standard emphasize safety and stability.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion applies the Massachusetts “best interests of the child” custody standard and explicitly focuses on what arrangement will minimize disruption and foster a healthy environment for the children. In rejecting joint custody and limiting visitation, the court emphasizes the children’s welfare in light of parental conflict, the need to avoid “continued warfare and conflict,” and the importance of continuity with the primary nurturing parent. This shows the standard is applied with a strong emphasis on the children’s safety, stability, and orderly development.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children. … [T]he judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: Cases interpreting this standard emphasize safety and stability.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion applies the general Massachusetts standard that custody determinations are governed by the ‘welfare of the child,’ considering present and probable future welfare, but it does not specifically frame or emphasize that standard in terms of ‘safety and stability.’ While the facts involve emotional harm and instability from parental conflict, the court’s articulated principle is child welfare broadly, not a distinct emphasis on safety and stability as such. Thus, using this case to support the precise proposition is somewhat overreading it.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule… In providing for the custody of a minor child… the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future…”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 871 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: A modification is appropriate where enforcement of the current order would endanger the child’s welfare.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The case is a removal and modification case, but it does not articulate or apply a standard that a modification is appropriate where enforcement of the current order would endanger the child’s welfare. Instead, it discusses the Yannas ‘real advantage’ and best-interests framework for removal and clarifies that a custodial parent’s remarriage can constitute a real advantage. There is no holding or analysis about modification being warranted specifically when continued enforcement of an existing order would endanger the child’s welfare.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28… ‘Upon a complaint after a divorce…, the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.’”
